Award.AwardTitle: US/UK Joint Workshop on Social and Behavioral Epigenetics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Epigenetics (literally, "above the gene") is a field of science which studies stable alterations in gene expression which occur through modifications which do not alter the sequence composition of DNA, yet which produce stable alterations in phenotypes (the physical expression of the genome). There is growing evidence that these epigenetic factors are responsive to environmental exposures both pre- and post-natally in animals, including humans; very importantly, these factors influencing gene expression include aspects of the social and behavioral environments. Factors such as varying aspects of the nurturing environment for infants and young children, socioeconomic circumstances, degrees and forms of stress experienced by individuals, and substance abuse, for example, are implicated in long-lasting biological and behavioral effects which may be mediated by epigenetic mechanisms - and these effects may not only persist into and throughout adulthood, but some may transcend generations, the effects being seen in offspring and grand-offspring of impacted individuals. As these social, behavioral, and psychological environmental influences on the epigenetic programming of biological and behavioral functioning can substantially impact human well-being and resilience, the science constituting the field of social and behavioral epigenetics is critically important. The societal benefits of the research in the field potentially will extend to impacts in areas such as human development and aging; memory, cognition, neuropsychology, stress, and learning; nutrition and nutritional issues such as obesity; substance abuse; violence; human biological functioning/variation and its adaptive/evolutionary significance; adaptation/maladaptation to rapid social and environmental change; and 'downstream' impacts on human health.

The complexity of the science, including the need to integrate fields of social science, as well as those sciences with aspects of the biological sciences, supports the need for synthesis of a research agenda that can most effectively advance the field, including both short- and long-term goals. This workshop is specifically designed to develop this agenda and thereby guide the targeting and the breadth of funding required to advance social and behavioral epigenetic research. The international scope of the workshop - bringing together the most active and influential members of the US and UK research communities developing this science of global interest and importance - also will provide opportunity to compare perspectives, approaches, and resources which can be leveraged to move the field forward.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On July 29-30, 2014, the first Workshop on Social and Behavioral Epigenetics was held in Potomac, MD. The goal was to identify gaps in knowledge or critically important questions that must be addressed in order for the field of social and behavioral epigenetics (SBE) to mature and reach its full potential. The workshop was attended by 40 scientists from the US, UK and Canada who were drawn equally from the biological and social sciences. The National Science Foundation (NSF grant BCS-1448213), Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, and UK Science & Innovation Network, Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC), Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC) and Research Councils UK (RCUK) provided the funding and initial impetus for the workshop, a rare collaboration attesting to the strong interest and support for the field.

 

Prior to the workshop, participants were asked to response in writing to two questions querying their thoughts on the most important questions to address in the future and obstacles to effectively addressing those questions. Participant responses were used to organize ten breakout sessions during the workshop. Two different groups of participants addressed each of the ten sets of questions. Ultimately, workshop participants identified twelve critical research topics and made four top research priorities and top organizational recommendations.

-          Information on the organization and recommendations of the workshop was written up in a final report that was submitted to NSF and posted online (www.nichd.nih.gov/about/meetings/2014/Documents/ExecSocialBehavEpigenetics_Sum.pdf).

-          In addition to the final report, the workshop and participant recommendations have been cited in multiple publications, including Mulligan, Ann Rev Anthro, in press and Mulligan, Am Anthropologist, in press.

-          One of the workshop organizational recommendations was to offer a statistical workshop to train biological and social scientists in the relevant methods for analysis of SBE data. Permission was obtained from NSF to use money remaining from the workshop grant to host a statistical workshop in July 29-31, 2015, focused on analysis of Illumina 450K Bead Chip data. Sixteen researchers from the US, UK and Canada, drawn from the biological and social sciences, attended the workshop. Formal assessment of the workshop indicated very high satisfaction with the workshop and interest in follow-up workshops focused on integrated analysis of biological and social science data, as well as additional analysis of DNA methylation data.

The Workshop on Social and Behavioral Epigenetics was very successful in bringing together scientists from around the world who work on issues related to social and behavioral epigenetics. Many participants met for the first time at the workshop and the goal is to develop new collaborations that leverage each scientist’s strengths. Future workshops are being planned, with a broader vision that will not just focus on epigenetic data, but highlight the integration of epigenetic/genetic/biological data with psychosocial/sociocultural data to provide the most comprehensive vision of human variation.
